awd_titl_txt: West Coast Precipitation Processes as Modulated by Storm Structure and Terrain
awd_abstract_narration:
Mountainous terrain has a significant impact on the amount and distribution of precipitation when large storms pass through.  In the winter of 2015-2016, a field campaign was conducted in the Olympic peninsula of Washington state to study precipitation near coastal terrain.  This follow-up project will use that data to answer questions about possible mechanisms involved in the enhancement of precipitation by mountains.  These events have high societal impact and further understanding of the specifics of their development will aid future forecasts.  The project also includes student training, outreach to the public, and is led by two females, a group that is underrepresented in the atmospheric science community. 

The research team plans to improve the understanding of precipitation processes in wintertime mid-latitude landfalling cyclones and determine how these processes are modulated by synoptic conditions and terrain.  The researchers would use observational data collected during the 2015-16 Olympia Mountains Experiment (OLYMPEX).  The OLYMPEX campaign consisted of a host of ground-based precipitation sites, multiple radars, and two research aircraft.  The researchers plan to use that data to answer two main scientific questions:  1) How do the effects of mountains on mid-latitude cyclone precipitation vary as each sector of a storm passes over the windward slope, high terrain, and leeside of the Olympic Mountains?, and 2) What are the key microphysical and dynamical processes operating during these variations?
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
One of the outstanding challenges in meteorology today is to understand the processes that affect precipitation in mountainous regions. During the winter months, moisture laden midlatitude cyclones transect coastal mountains and often produce floods on the windward slopes, increase the winter snowpack in the high terrain, and lead to a rainshadow (i.e.,a lack of precipitation) on the lee side. The goals of this project were to understand the processes that control the creation, distribution, and intensity of precipitation in winter storms and to determine how these processes are modulated by environmental conditions and terrain. Our approach to explore this goal was through the analysis of datasets collected during the Olympic Mountains Experiment (OLYMPEX). OLYMPEX was a multi-faceted, multi-agency, international field campaign that took place over the Olympic Mountains in the northwest corner of Washington State during fall 2015 - spring 2016. The data assets of OLYMPEX covered both the windward and lee sides of the Olympic Mountains. This project focused on the analysis of ground-based radar, surface disdrometers and rain gauges, and in situ and remote sensing data collected from multiple aircraft. 

 

One overarching finding that has resulted from multiple studies funded by this grant is that the most pronounced modification of precipitation processes by complex terrain occurs under environmental conditions observed predominantly during the warm sector periods of midlatitude cyclones. These conditions include high melting layer height, strong low-level flow impinging orthogonally on the Olympic Mountains, high values of integrated water vapor in the upstream airflow, and near-neutral low-level stability. Under these conditions, moist low-level flow is lifted when it encounters the terrain, and the warm-rain processes of collection and coalescence make significant contributions to the total observed rainfall on the windward slopes. These processes are especially important during flood-producing storms. In addition, broad lifting of the entire moist column produces enhancement in the ice-layer above the melting level over terrain compared to the same levels over the ocean before the precipitating system encounters terrain. The implications of these findings is that the ice-layer and mixed-phase precipitation processes above the melting layer also contribute to orographic precipitation enhancement on the windward slopes and loft ice particles over the terrain towards the lee side, decreasing the lee-side rain shadow. 

 

The results from this work have a broad impact on numerical modeling of storms, remote sensing of precipitation from space, and on the field of hydrology. The key finding of the importance of warm-rain processes during heavy precipitation events has led to other projects to improve the representation of warm-rain processes in numerical model microphysical schemes. This will ultimately lead to more accurate rainfall prediction during high impact flooding events, especially in mountainous terrain. Precipitation estimates in complex terrain are difficult to obtain from space-borne instruments, but the results from this work point to ways to improve the precipitation retrievals. Understanding of the processes and conditions that lead to snowfall accumulation over high terrain and the lee side of mountains will ultimately lead to better water management in those regions. 


One key outcome of this project was the concerted effort to reach out to local communities on the Olympic Peninsula. Through education and outreach activities, we engaged with students, teachers, and the broader public on the benefits of scientific research, how weather on the Olympic Peninsula affects their daily lives, and how their communities helped make OLYMPEX a success. These efforts were mutually beneficial in gaining insight from those who have lived on these lands for generations and in highlighting new insights gained from our recent research efforts. We are especially grateful for the partnerships and engagement with the Indian Nations of the Olympic Peninsula. Additionally, this project was led by women, which increased visibility in leadership and mentorship roles and improved representation for students and others in the community.
